item.title: GUI not appearing?
item.dc:creator: @light232 light232
item.description:
@light232 wrote:

[quote=“lesterknome, post:8, topic:301854”]Final Product as of now, tell me how it looks:

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;


/**
 *
 * @author Lester Knome
 */
public class GUI extends JFrame {

    public Main main = new Main();

    public GUI() {
        super("Lester Knome's IRC Client");
        init(); // Start up the GUI
    }

    public void init() { //initialize all the GUI components
        //TODO: Add GUI
        this.setTitle("Lester Knome's IRC Client");
	this.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        chatArea = new JTextArea();
        jScrollPane1 = new JScrollPane();

        chatArea.setColumns(20);
        chatArea.setRows(5);
        jScrollPane1.setViewportView(chatArea);

        this.add(chatArea);

        // And Finally,
        this.setResizable(false);
        this.setVisible(true);
	this.pack();
        notify();
    }
    
    public static void Print(String Text) {
        chatArea.append(Text + nline);
    }

    // GUI Components
    protected static JTextArea chatArea;
    private JScrollPane jScrollPane1;
    private static String nline = "\n";
}

New question: This will be a IRC client obviously, so how big should the actual program be and how big should the text area be?[/quote]
still sloppy, look at the code i pasted above

Read full topic

item.title: GUI not appearing?
item.dc:creator: @jimmy5410 jimmy5410
item.description:
@jimmy5410 wrote:

[code] chatArea.setColumns(20);
chatArea.setRows(5);
jScrollPane1.setViewportView(chatArea);

    this.add(chatArea);[/code]

Why are you placing the JTextArea in a jscrollpane, but proceeding to add the JTextArea to the jframe? Add the jscrollpane to the jframe’s contentPane.

Read full topic

item.title: GUI not appearing?
item.dc:creator: @lesterknome lesterknome
item.description:
@lesterknome wrote:

Final Product as of now, tell me how it looks:

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;


/**
 *
 * @author Lester Knome
 */
public class GUI extends JFrame {

    public Main main = new Main();

    public GUI() {
        super("Lester Knome's IRC Client");
        init(); // Start up the GUI
    }

    public void init() { //initialize all the GUI components
        //TODO: Add GUI
        this.setTitle("Lester Knome's IRC Client");
	this.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        chatArea = new JTextArea();
        jScrollPane1 = new JScrollPane();

        chatArea.setColumns(20);
        chatArea.setRows(5);
        jScrollPane1.setViewportView(chatArea);

        this.add(chatArea);

        // And Finally,
        this.setResizable(false);
        this.setVisible(true);
	this.pack();
        notify();
    }
    
    public static void Print(String Text) {
        chatArea.append(Text + nline);
    }

    // GUI Components
    protected static JTextArea chatArea;
    private JScrollPane jScrollPane1;
    private static String nline = "\n";
}

New question: This will be a IRC client obviously, so how big should the actual program be and how big should the text area be?

item.title: GUI not appearing?
item.dc:creator: @light232 light232
item.description:
@light232 wrote:

[quote=“lesterknome, post:1, topic:301854”]Here is my GUI class:

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;


/**
 *
 * @author Lester Knome
 */
public class GUI extends JFrame {

    public Main main = new Main();

    public GUI() {
        init(); // Start up the GUI
    }

    public void init() { //initialize all the GUI components
        //TODO: Add GUI
        frame = new JFrame("Lester Knome's IRC Client");
	frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        chatArea = new JTextArea();
        jScrollPane1 = new JScrollPane();

        chatArea.setColumns(20);
        chatArea.setRows(5);
        jScrollPane1.setViewportView(chatArea);

        // And Finally,
        frame.setVisible(true);
	frame.pack();
    }
    
    public static void Print(String Text) {
        chatArea.append(Text + nline);
    }

    // GUI Components
    protected static JTextArea chatArea;
    private JScrollPane jScrollPane1;
    private JFrame frame;
    private static String nline = "\n";
}

All that appears is the actual frame, nothing else.[/quote]
private static String nline = “\n”;
you do know that can be a char
private static char nline = ‘\n’;[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 12, 2009, 11:13:56 am[/size][hr][code]
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JScrollPane;
import javax.swing.JTextArea;

/**
*

  • @author Light232(light232@hotmail.com)
    */
    public final class GUI extends JFrame {

    private final JTextArea textArea;
    private final JScrollPane textAreaScroll;

    public GUI() {
    super(“Swing GUI”);//(title)
    this.textArea = new JTextArea(5, 20);//(rows, columns)
    this.textAreaScroll = new JScrollPane(this.textArea);//(view)
    this.setup();
    }

    private void setup() {
    super.setSize(100, 100);
    this.textArea.setSize(99, 99);
    this.textAreaScroll.setSize(100, 100);//as big a our frame is
    super.add(this.textAreaScroll);
    super.setVisible(true);
    super.pack();
    }

    public void append(String text) {
    this.textArea.append(text);
    }

    /* just a test */
    public static void main(String… args) {
    GUI gui = new GUI();
    for(int i = 0; i != 30; i++) {
    gui.append(“Test [” + i + “]\n”);
    }
    }

}[/code]

item.title: GUI not appearing?
item.dc:creator: @Zero_Freeze ZeroFreeze
item.description:
@Zero_Freeze wrote:

lesterknome:

Thanks, my first time working with swing without using a GUI builder

You should learn the ins and outs of swing and its usage before availing yourself of a GUI designer…

item.title: GUI not appearing?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Since you are extending JFrame, the first call in your constructor should be ‘super(“your title here”);’ to call JFrame’s constructor. There are other problems as well but I would call that your main one.

Read full topic

item.title: GUI not appearing?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“lesterknome, post:3, topic:301854”]Thanks, my first time working with swing without using a GUI builder

EDIT: Okay, now this is what i have now.

[code]
import javax.swing.;
import java.awt.;

/**
*

  • @author Lester Knome
    */
    public class GUI extends JFrame {

    public Main main = new Main();

    public GUI() {
    init(); // Start up the GUI
    }

    public void init() { //initialize all the GUI components
    //TODO: Add GUI
    new JFrame(“Lester Knome’s IRC Client”);
    this.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
    chatArea = new JTextArea();
    jScrollPane1 = new JScrollPane();

     chatArea.setColumns(20);
 chatArea.setRows(5);
 jScrollPane1.setViewportView(chatArea);

 this.add(chatArea);

 // And Finally,
 this.setVisible(true);

    this.pack();
    notify();
    }

    public static void Print(String Text) {
    chatArea.append(Text + nline);
    }

    // GUI Components
    protected static JTextArea chatArea;
    private JScrollPane jScrollPane1;
    private static String nline = “\n”;
    }
    [/code][/quote]

There’s no point in doing [tt]new JFrame()[/tt]. And, why are you doing [tt]notify()[/tt]? As far as I can see, there are no threads waiting on that object. And even if they were, you do not have the correct monitor state to notify any waiting threads.

Read full topic

item.title: GUI not appearing?
item.dc:creator: @lesterknome lesterknome
item.description:
@lesterknome wrote:

Thanks, my first time working with swing without using a GUI builder

EDIT: Okay, now this is what i have now.

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;


/**
 *
 * @author Lester Knome
 */
public class GUI extends JFrame {

    public Main main = new Main();

    public GUI() {
        init(); // Start up the GUI
    }

    public void init() { //initialize all the GUI components
        //TODO: Add GUI
        new JFrame("Lester Knome's IRC Client");
	this.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        chatArea = new JTextArea();
        jScrollPane1 = new JScrollPane();

        chatArea.setColumns(20);
        chatArea.setRows(5);
        jScrollPane1.setViewportView(chatArea);

        this.add(chatArea);

        // And Finally,
        this.setVisible(true);
	this.pack();
        notify();
    }
    
    public static void Print(String Text) {
        chatArea.append(Text + nline);
    }

    // GUI Components
    protected static JTextArea chatArea;
    private JScrollPane jScrollPane1;
    private static String nline = "\n";
}

item.title: GUI not appearing?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Why would you store a JFrame field when GUI extends JFrame? Just remove the [tt]frame[/tt] field and treat [tt]this[/tt] as your JFrame.

You also never called [tt]JFrame.add(Component)[/tt], so how is something supposed to appear?

Edit: Take a look at this tutorial. The source code to the program they describe should help you.

Read full topic

item.title: GUI not appearing?
item.dc:creator: @lesterknome lesterknome
item.description:
@lesterknome wrote:

Here is my GUI class:

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;


/**
 *
 * @author Lester Knome
 */
public class GUI extends JFrame {

    public Main main = new Main();

    public GUI() {
        init(); // Start up the GUI
    }

    public void init() { //initialize all the GUI components
        //TODO: Add GUI
        frame = new JFrame("Lester Knome's IRC Client");
	frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        chatArea = new JTextArea();
        jScrollPane1 = new JScrollPane();

        chatArea.setColumns(20);
        chatArea.setRows(5);
        jScrollPane1.setViewportView(chatArea);

        // And Finally,
        frame.setVisible(true);
	frame.pack();
    }
    
    public static void Print(String Text) {
        chatArea.append(Text + nline);
    }

    // GUI Components
    protected static JTextArea chatArea;
    private JScrollPane jScrollPane1;
    private JFrame frame;
    private static String nline = "\n";
}

All that appears is the actual frame, nothing else.
